data.title: Missing editorGroupHeader colorization option
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.13.1
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.04

![sc_vs_code](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2027300/28017876-3b535014-65a5-11e7-8f7f-b2bf6bfba076.png)

There seems to be no editable foreground color properties for **editorGroupHeader** in the **workbench.colorCustomizations** option. What I want to do is to change the color of the icons on the top right corner of the editor. Options that are available: editorGroupHeader.tabsBackground, editorGroupHeader.noTabsBackground, and editorGroupHeader.tabsBorder.

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Flickering when switching themes
data.body:
- open some source code (e.g. of type Java)
- Open the theme switcher dialog
- go through the themes
- note that the token colors flicker
- it looks to me (from debugging at ViewLine.renderLine) that there is a moment where each line has all scopes removed from the lines, and that all text gets draws with the default foreground color (mtk1)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6461412/28006870-bea971cc-6583-11e7-8b6d-af7f9d2504bc.png)

data.title: Some terminal text invisible with the default Solarized Dark theme
data.body: - VSCode Version: Code 1.13.1 (379d2efb5539b09112c793d3d9a413017d736f89, 2017-06-14T18:13:05.928Z) - OS Version: Darwin x64 16.6.0 - Extensions: |Extension|Author|Version| |---|---|---| |xml|DotJoshJohnson|1.9.2| |pegjs-language|SirTobi|0.1.0| |python|donjayamanne|0.6.7| |Theme-Solarized-dark|gerane|0.0.2| |ftp-simple|humy2833|0.5.1| |cpptools|ms-vscode|0.12.0| |csharp|ms-vscode|1.11.0| |latex|ms-vscode|0.1.3| |debugger-for-chrome|msjsdiag|3.1.6| |java|redhat|0.7.0| |vscode-icons|robertohuertasm|7.10.1| |sass-indented|robinbentley|1.4.1|; --- I encountered this when using the *default* Solarized Dark theme (not to be confused with the `Solarized-Dark` theme module, which works fine.) and mocha 3.0.2. Steps to Reproduce: 1. Install mocha (my version is 3.0.2) 2. Write a simple test script, save as `test.js`, for example: describe("test", () => { it("test 1", () => { }); it("test 2", () => { }); }); 3. Use the default "Solarized Dark" theme 4. Open the VSCode Terminal, type "mocha `test.js`" The test names such as `test 1` and `test 2` are missing because the background color is the same as the text colors for them.

data.title: C# Intellisense does not refresh after class (symbol) rename and also adding Nuget package
data.body:
<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.13.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 Pro

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Rename a class - or adding a NuGet package using dotnet add package <packagename>
At this point the intellisense error highlighter indicates that the referenced classes have an error (in the case of a renamed class is says the class and ctor already exist, in the case of a newly added package, it says it cannot find it.

To work around this I have to restart VS Code.
<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: No.. but this disabled the 'Rename Symbol' option and it also disabled the intellisense - so kind of a mute point (I think?).

data.title: SCM: actions disabled when doing a git operation
data.body:
Steps to Reproduce:

1. vscode workspace
2. have some outgoing changes
3. have each file open that has outgoing changes
4. undo a change from one file
5. directly right click another file => open file

The first time "Open File" is invoked does nothing, only the second time something happens. 

I think this is related to not seeing a diff when clicking on a file after making a git operation (e.g. staging).

2. add some bash script into the editor but w/o saving it
3. set the language mode the shell script (bash)

data.title: Tab title uses parent for specified file names

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body: This is my take for issues #27328 and #12965. In the settings is now possible to specify an array of file names, i.e. `"workbench.editor.tabTitleUsesParentFor": ["index.js", "template.hbs"]`. This controls if we should emphasise parent directory name when there are opened editors with the specified file name. In the screenshot there's the outcome of this PR: for the files specified, the parent directory is highlighted, for the others nothing changes (so if there's no ambiguity the file name is shown, otherwise the file name + path). If this approach is considered valid, I'm open to suggestions on how to improve the code. Probably move all the logic inside the already existing method getUniqueTabLabels?

data.title: Explorer tab scrolling when switching to different file
data.body:
When switching to a different opened file tab, the explorer will scroll to the currently active tab, which can be annoying especially if you're going thru the files of a large project.
It would be better if we could disable this feature, so that when we open a file , the explorer scrollbar stays at its current position and not scroll towards the last opened file.
Thanks in advance

data.title: Add toggleTabsVisibility to keybinding actions
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.13.1 (379d2efb5539b09112c793d3d9a413017d736f89, 2017-06-14T18:13:05.928Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.1.0
- Extensions: the listing length exceeds browsers' URL characters limit
---

| Element | Toggled Setting | Keybinding Command | Contextually Located Keybinding*** |
|:-:|:-:|:-:|:-:|
| Tabs | `workbench.editor.showTabs`  | `workbench.action.toggleTabsVisibility` ** | `ctrl+cmd+w` |
| ActivityBar | `workbench.activityBar.visible` | `workbench.action.toggleActivityBarVisibility` | `ctrl+cmd+a` |
| Sidebar | * | `workbench.action.toggleSidebarVisibility` | `ctrl+cmd+s` |
| Statusbar | `workbench.statusBar.visible` | `workbench.action.toggleStatusBarVisibility` | `ctrl+cmd+x` |


\* As far I could tell, there is no *workbench.statusBar.visible*, only *workbench.sideBar.location*.

\*\* Proposed keybindings action 
* I wrote its prefix as such as the other toggleable areas are in `/workbench/browser/actions/` even though the settings is under `workbench.editor` and as I didn't find  ```editor/actions``` section or the sort. But I am unfamiliar with the conventions and structure of this project. ¯\\_(ツ)\_/¯.
  * Perhaps change `workbench.editor.showTabs` -> `workbench.tabBar.visible` to follow suite?

\*\*\* These are my own keybindings I use for the commands. Their positions on a keyboard (qwerty) make them easy to reach and physically represent what area of the editor they are toggling. 
* For windows users `cmd` -> `alt`

data.title: Vscode Insider trimming trailing whitespace on save by default.
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.14.0-inside
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1.Add trailing whitespace to any file
2.Save, the whitespace is trimmed even though i'm not explicitly telling the editor to do so.

I have added trailing spaces to clearly show this issue.

Here is what happens when you save with the latest insider build.

![deletewhitespace](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16381287/27996497-05825060-64b1-11e7-8f1c-7a827b9f0a6f.gif)


And here is what happens in the latest stable build.

![savewhitespace](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16381287/27996498-0f0ffb82-64b1-11e7-8179-3e4836eb73e8.gif)

this is even happening with `"files.trimTrailingWhitespace": false,` is set explicitly, even thought it is disabled by default.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

edit: please close, for some reason a reinstall, even with my same plugins and settings seems to have completely fixed this issue.

data.title: Feature Request: "Assign to new local variable" refactoring
data.body:
In Eclipse JDT, there's this really handy shortcut, mapped to `CTRL+2 L` by default, which works when an expression is selected. What it does is to create a new local variable to hold the result of the expression. For example...

`this.doSomeCalculation();`

If the mouse cursor is positioned over the line above, `CTRL+2 L` will turn the line into...

`double someCalculation = this.doSomeCalculation()`

I find myself using this shortcut a lot when coding Java. It assigns the correct typebound and proposes a sensible default name for the variable, based on the name of the called method. Having something similar for Typescript in VSCode would be very handy. With all the typing information that the Typescript environment has, this should be possible, right?

data.title: VS Code as code editor for LibreOffice (and other applications)
data.body:
Currently, LibreOffice (and variants) allow embedding scripts/macros inside a document, in one of four languages, each with a different editor with very different UIs:

* StarOffice Basic -- using the built-in Basic code editor
* BeanShell -- using a packaged BeanShell editor
* Javascript -- using a packaged instance of the Rhino Javascript environment
* Python -- no built in editing support; files have to be added manually

Is it feasible to leverage VS Code for all of these scenarios?

I think this would be greatly appealing to the LibreOffice project, providing a single advanced cross-platform code editor with Intellisense and debugging capabilities. VS Code already has language support for Javascript (built-in) and Python (extension); creating language server extensions for other languages should be relatively straightforward. The procedure for [writing a debugger extension](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/extensions/example-debuggers) is well-defined; I imagine it should be possible to write an extension to LibreOffice that would convert it into a debugger adapter.

I realize it would require an extension installed into LibreOffice, but the issue here is what would be required on the VS Code side (built-in, or via an extension).

I think there is one major hurdle. LibreOffice by default uses files in the OpenDocument format, which are ZIP files with text files as contents (they inspired Office Open XML). Script files are stored within the ZIP file, under `/Scripts/<language>`. VS Code is highly oriented to files and folders on disk. Is it possible to bridge this gap? I can see two approaches:

1. **Mount the entire ZIP file to a filesystem mountpoint, then VS Code will be able to create, edit, and save documents normally.** This is problematic, because the Solution Explorer will expose the entire contents of the file, not only the scripts/macros. While this theoretically _might_ be useful in certain scenarios, there is the danger that the user could edit different parts of the file contents in various ways unsupported by the OpenDocument format.
2. **All interactions with the scripts would be through the application's API** -- Solution Explorer would display the tree hierarchy returned by the API, creating/editing/deleting files would also be done through the application's API. Does VS Code support this kind of scenario?

Note: Solving this problem would open the way for other applications to easily use VS Code as their script editors.  Specifically, there is a highly-voted UserVoice item for [using Python or R embedded in Excel](https://excel.uservoice.com/forums/304921-excel-for-windows-desktop-application/suggestions/10549005-python-as-an-excel-scripting-language). If VS Code could be leveraged in this way, then it would allow any language/debugger supported by VS Code to be similarly embedded in Office documents.
